Award.AwardTitle: Identification of Postseismic Transients in PBO GPS Time-Series
Award.AbstractNarration: The success of PBO's mission to infer long-term steady-state surface velocities depends critically on the ability of geodesists to identify and remove all non-steady-state contributions to GPS time series. Without this ability, steady-state velocities will be misidentified, leading to a misinterpretation of long-term strain rates and stress accumulation and an undermining of our understanding of the tectonics of North America. Of all non-steady-state contributions to GPS time series, postseismic relaxation of the lower crust and upper mantle has the potential for the greatest long-term influence on the broadest regions. In this project, viscoelastic finite element models are being developed to identify for removal from PBO GPS displacement time series, postseismic transients associated with all large (M greater than or equal to 7) earthquakes in the past several hundred years in the southwestern US and Alaska. The most important aspect of this analysis is finding a constitutive relationship between strain rate and stress that can appropriately characterize nonlinear viscoelastic strength as a function of tectonic environment (stress, temperature, water). This is especially true in consideration of nonlinear changes in viscosity associated with stress, which leads to a viscosity structure that varies spatially and temporally after an earthquake, and an initial transient response to stress changes that are much weaker than steady-state flow. To this end a new transient/steady-state power law is being introduced that combines the biviscous characterization of a Burgers model with the temperature and stress-dependent nature of a laboratory derived power law. The main objectives of this work are to: (1) calibrate this new transient/steady-state power-law to characterize the response of lower crustal and upper mantle flow through the earthquake cycle in the western US and mainland Alaska, and (2) use the flow law to calculate postseismic relaxation components in PBO GPS displacement time series associated with all large (M greater than or equal to 7) earthquakes in the past 100-200 years in these regions. These regions were chosen because they contain the bulk of the PBO network and they have experienced a significant number of M greater than or equal to 7 earthquakes. Secondary objectives include the determination of whether a single flow law can be used to describe the rheological strength of both the western US and Alaska margins, which will tell us something about the homogeneity versus heterogeneity of rheological properties at plate margins, and the development of a general understanding of the spatial and temporal influence of postseismic relaxation as a function of earthquake magnitude, which will provide insight into which historical earthquakes are continuing to influence the contemporary velocity field, and the likely duration of influence from more recent events. The analysis is being conducted using the finite element program ABAQUS, which enables the development of the required complex meshes and the incorporation of the new transient/steady-state power law. This project has the potential to improve the accuracy of one of the central missions of PBO: to infer long-term steady-state surface velocities and strain rates. Thus, it has the potential to influence a very broad number of research projects throughout the Earthscope community -- any project that utilizes GPS time series.

Our understanding of tectonic processes such as mountain building and earthquakes is based on the theory that the Earth is covered by a number of tectonic plates—a cold, strong crust and uppermost mantle broken into about a dozen major pieces. These plates float over a weak substrate of warm rock (mantle). We know a fair amount about the rocks on top that break, but not much about those underneath that flow viscously because they are too deep to directly observe. An indirect method to understand the nature of viscous flow is to take a small rock specimens and squeeze them in the laboratory under different conditions (e.g., temperature, stress) and observe how they flow. While this is informative, it has limited utility use since we are not sure exactly what mineral assemblages lie beneath the plates, nor the conditions that are controlling how they flow. A more direct means is to use earthquakes themselves as large rock squeezing experiments. Though earthquake relieve stress in the crust, they also impart a stress increase below in the lower crust and upper mantle. Since these deep rocks are hot and relatively weak, they cannot sustain these stress changes and viscously flow in response. This causes stresses to migrate upwards and deform the surface in the months and years following an earthquake. Called postseismic deformations, these displacements can be measured by various techniques, such as high precision GPS. These observed displacements can then by used to constraint numerical models of the relaxation process—enabling us to test various candidate rheologies (viscous strength).

Postseismic studies have been on-going for about a decade, ever since high precision GPS and satellite interferometry (InSAR) were put out in the field to recorded earthquake and postseismic deformation. Such studies, however, generally only attempt to infer how viscosity varies as a function of depth. Laboratory rock squeezing experiments, however, suggest a more complicated rheology, including temperature- and stress-dependence, as well as strong non-linear behavior to sudden changes in stress. To this end the main goals of this project were to combined what we learn in the laboratory regarding how rocks flow in response to their tectonic environment to displacements we observed following earthquakes. We initially look at postseismic displacements following a pair of earthquake in the Mojave Desert, the 1992 M7.2 Landers and 1999 M7.0 Hector Mine earthquakes. We developed a numerical model that simulated the slip on the faults and used the model to predict postseismic surface displacements. Most importantly, we incorporated what are know as steady-state (as if flow had been occurring for a long time) relationships between flow rates and the tectonic environment (mineralogy, temperature, stress, water content, etc.). We found that no combination of laboratory derived flow law parameters or plausible tectonic conditions could be used to explain the observed postseismic deformations. Specifically, steady-state flow laws could not explain very fast early postseismic displacements.

Our second study followed by testing a laboratory-derived transient flow law, also temperature- and stress-dependent. A transient flow law enables initially faster viscous flow in response to a sudden change in the laboratory, a phenomenon observed often in laboratory rock squeezing experiments. This flow law proved very successful in being able to predict postseismic displacements. Most importantly, since we used a temperature- and stress-dependent rheology, we were able infer (for the first time) the temperature and stress-state of the flowing rocks were experiencing.
